message.raw:
Ensure number of levels in the dataframe does not decrease.

This fixes a bug where the number of levels is incorrect after all shots are
deleted and shots with fewer levels are loaded. We could allow the number of
levels to decrease, but this is more trouble than it is worth since we store
previously-seen columns so that their visibility can be restored if they are
seen again. Since their levels cannot be reduced, comparing them with other
columns is difficult. There is surely a cleaner way to deal with all this,
but it will require more work, whereas the bug is fixed by simply ensuring that
the number of column levels never shrinks.

Ensure number of levels in the dataframe does not decrease.

This fixes a bug where the number of levels is incorrect after all shots are
deleted and shots with fewer levels are loaded. We could allow the number of
levels to decrease, but this is more trouble than it is worth since we store

message.raw:
Different approach: use new method infer_objects.
Do replace the shot model's stored dataframe in-place. This minimises the number
of columns that need converting each time, ensuring we don't wastefully do the
same conversion over and over. Do this replacement in the GUI thread to ensure
it is atomic with respect to dataframe updates.

message.raw:
Fix for issue #52. Remove deprecated convert_objects() call.

In current versions of pandas and lyse, in normal use the majority of dataframe
columns that can be are already specific datatypes and not 'object', so there is
limited performance improvement to this.

Some colums that were temporarily a mixed datatype (due to the analysis
results being saved by single shot routines changing type) will remain dtype
object even if all the entries are later of the same type, which is not ideal.

This should be rare and so not likely to be a performance problem, which was the
original purpose of adding convert_objects. But these columns may appear differently
from the perspective of multishot routines, and some code may not be able to handle
them. However we will see empirically if this causes any problems, as perhaps
all relevant code can in fact handle the mixed datatypes fine, so we shouldn't
fix what isn't broken.

message.raw:
Fix issue #50: close button unresponsive if there are no routines

It seems like QMainWindow.close() cannot be called whilst a close event is
currently being handled. Delay call to close() until the mainloop is idle.

Force multiprocessing to spawn new processes instead of forking them on >= 3.4.

This fixes issue #49 which was caused by forking, but zeromq not being fork-safe.

message.raw:
Fix two issues with delayed closing of lyse

* There was a bug where if no configuration changed, Lyse.on_close_event
  would not terminate the subprocesses, and then it would wait the full
  two seconds before quitting (and potentially leave any non-zprocess subprocesses
  running). Refactored on_close_event(), factoring out the 'are you sure' dialog
  and the termination of all subprocesses into separate functions while fixing
  the logic here.
* When lyse was to actually quit, it called qapplication.quit() instead of .close()
  on the main window. This means if running with `python -i`, lyse doesn't actually
  close, as the event loop just fires back up again. Now it actally calls close(),
  and this triggers the same method that caught the first close event, which knows
  it's the second time it's been called because a flag has been set so actually closes.
  This also has the side effect that the user clicking close twice will close
  lyse regardless of the timeout (which seems fine).
message.html:
Fix two issues with delayed closing of lyse

  • There was a bug where if no configuration changed, Lyse.on_close_event
    would not terminate the subprocesses, and then it would wait the full
    two seconds before quitting (and potentially leave any non-zprocess subprocesses
    running). Refactored on_close_event(), factoring out the 'are you sure' dialog
    and the termination of all subprocesses into separate functions while fixing
    the logic here.
  • When lyse was to actually quit, it called qapplication.quit() instead of .close()
    on the main window. This means if running with python -i, lyse doesn't actually
    close, as the event loop just fires back up again. Now it actally calls close(),
    and this triggers the same method that caught the first close event, which knows
    it's the second time it's been called because a flag has been set so actually closes.
    This also has the side effect that the user clicking close twice will close
    lyse regardless of the timeout (which seems fine).

summary.raw:
Fix two issues with delayed closing of lyse

* There was a bug where if no configuration changed, Lyse.on_close_event
  would not terminate the subprocesses, and then it would wait the full
  two seconds before quitting (and potentially leave any non-zprocess subprocesses
  running). Refactored on_close_event(), factoring out the 'are you sure' dialog
  and the termination of all subprocesses into separate functions while fixing
  the logic here.
* When lyse was to actually quit, it called qapplication.quit() instead of .close()
  on the main window. This means if running with `python -i`, lyse doesn't actually
  close, as the event loop just fires back up again. Now it actally calls close(),
  and this triggers the same method that caught the first close event, which knows
  it's the second time it's been called because a flag has been set so actually closes.
  This also has the side effect that the user clicking close twice will close
  lyse regardless of the timeout (which seems fine).
summary.html:
Fix two issues with delayed closing of lyse

  • There was a bug where if no configuration changed, Lyse.on_close_event
    would not terminate the subprocesses, and then it would wait the full
    two seconds before quitting (and potentially leave any non-zprocess subprocesses
    running). Refactored on_close_event(), factoring out the 'are you sure' dialog
    and the termination of all subprocesses into separate functions while fixing
    the logic here.
  • When lyse was to actually quit, it called qapplication.quit() instead of .close()
    on the main window. This means if running with python -i, lyse doesn't actually
    close, as the event loop just fires back up again. Now it actally calls close(),
    and this triggers the same method that caught the first close event, which knows
    it's the second time it's been called because a flag has been set so actually closes.
    This also has the side effect that the user clicking close twice will close
    lyse regardless of the timeout (which seems fine).

values.message:
Fix two issues with delayed closing of lyse

* There was a bug where if no configuration changed, Lyse.on_close_event
  would not terminate the subprocesses, and then it would wait the full
  two seconds before quitting (and potentially leave any non-zprocess subprocesses
  running). Refactored on_close_event(), factoring out the 'are you sure' dialog
  and the termination of all subprocesses into separate functions while fixing
  the logic here.
* When lyse was to actually quit, it called qapplication.quit() instead of .close()
  on the main window. This means if running with `python -i`, lyse doesn't actually
  close, as the event loop just fires back up again. Now it actally calls close(),
  and this triggers the same method that caught the first close event, which knows
  it's the second time it's been called because a flag has been set so actually closes.
  This also has the side effect that the user clicking close twice will close
  lyse regardless of the timeout (which seems fine).

Import winshell non-lazily. This ensures winshell and its submodules are
whitelisted by ModuleWatcher. Requires labscript_utils pull request,
which will be stamped as labscript_utils 2.12.4

message.raw:
Attempt at a complete fix for issue #48. Create a module object for the user's
analysis routine and insert it into sys.modules as the `__main__` module
(and rename the analysis_subprocess module from `__main__` to
`_analysis_subprocess`). Run the user's code in that module's `__dict__`,
resetting the dict to its initial state each run.
message.html:
Attempt at a complete fix for issue #48. Create a module object for the user's
analysis routine and insert it into sys.modules as the __main__ module
(and rename the analysis_subprocess module from __main__ to
_analysis_subprocess). Run the user's code in that module's __dict__,
resetting the dict to its initial state each run.

analysis routine and insert it into sys.modules as the `__main__` module
(and rename the analysis_subprocess module from `__main__` to
`_analysis_subprocess`). Run the user's code in that module's `__dict__`,
resetting the dict to its initial state each run.

Attempt at a complete fix for issue #48. Create a module object for the user's
analysis routine and insert it into sys.modules as the `__main__` module
(and rename the analysis_subprocess module from `__main__` to
`_analysis_subprocess`). Run the user's code in that module's `__dict__`,
resetting the dict to its initial state each run.

message.raw:
analysis_subprocess.py: Move side-effecty code into `__main__` block.
This makes importing `analysis_subprocess` side-effect-free, making it not
interfere with the multiprocessing module when subprocesses execute it
(since it is the `__main__` module of the parent process)
message.html:

interfere with the multiprocessing module when subprocesses execute it
(since it is the __main__ module of the parent process)

message.raw:
Resolves issue #47. We could replace the (KeyError, ValueError) catch with
TypeError, but since the existence of the sequence_index column is guaranteed,
there's no need. Instead, check for a non-null value using pandas.notna.
message.html:
Resolves issue #47. We could replace the (KeyError, ValueError) catch with
TypeError, but since the existence of the sequence_index column is guaranteed,
there's no need. Instead, check for a non-null value using pandas.notna.

summary.raw:
Resolves issue #47. We could replace the (KeyError, ValueError) catch with

there's no need. Instead, check for a non-null value using pandas.notna.

Resolves issue #47. We could replace the (KeyError, ValueError) catch with

values.message:
Resolves issue #47. We could replace the (KeyError, ValueError) catch with
TypeError, but since the existence of the sequence_index column is guaranteed,
there's no need. Instead, check for a non-null value using pandas.notna.

message.raw:
Disable word wrap in FileBox QTableView

Line wrapping in the FileBox is not desired since we are not expanding cells
vertically, and if line wrapping is enabled the text is vertically centered
and so not even the first line is readable.

QTableView has word wrapping enabled by default, but Qt <= 5.11 had a bug such
that it had no effect. Qt 5.12 fixes this bug, resulting in the table wrapping
lines unless word wrapping is explicitly disabled as in this commit.
message.html:
Disable word wrap in FileBox QTableView

Line wrapping in the FileBox is not desired since we are not expanding cells
vertically, and if line wrapping is enabled the text is vertically centered
and so not even the first line is readable.

QTableView has word wrapping enabled by default, but Qt <= 5.11 had a bug such
that it had no effect. Qt 5.12 fixes this bug, resulting in the table wrapping
lines unless word wrapping is explicitly disabled as in this commit.

values.message:
Disable word wrap in FileBox QTableView

Line wrapping in the FileBox is not desired since we are not expanding cells
vertically, and if line wrapping is enabled the text is vertically centered
and so not even the first line is readable.

QTableView has word wrapping enabled by default, but Qt <= 5.11 had a bug such
that it had no effect. Qt 5.12 fixes this bug, resulting in the table wrapping
lines unless word wrapping is explicitly disabled as in this commit.

message.raw:
Merged in cbillington/lyse/absolute_paths (pull request #46)

Have lyse load all of its resources with absolute paths and do not chdir() into the lyse directory.

This helps avoid the problem of lyse's behaviour depending on what directory it was launched from due to chdir() not updating the __file__ attribute of modules, resulting in __file__ being wrong for relative paths.
message.html:
Merged in cbillington/lyse/absolute_paths (pull request #46)

Have lyse load all of its resources with absolute paths and do not chdir() into the lyse directory.

This helps avoid the problem of lyse's behaviour depending on what directory it was launched from due to chdir() not updating the file attribute of modules, resulting in file being wrong for relative paths.

message.raw:
Bugfix and remove deprecated code

* Ensure any bytestrings read from file attributes are turned into
  unicode strings.

* Remove pandas monkeypatch that has been included in pandas since
  version 0.21, which we now depend on.

* Remove an unused line of code.
message.html:
Bugfix and remove deprecated code

  • Ensure any bytestrings read from file attributes are turned into
    unicode strings.

  • Remove pandas monkeypatch that has been included in pandas since
    version 0.21, which we now depend on.

  • Remove an unused line of code.

values.message:
Bugfix and remove deprecated code

* Ensure any bytestrings read from file attributes are turned into
  unicode strings.

* Remove pandas monkeypatch that has been included in pandas since
  version 0.21, which we now depend on.

* Remove an unused line of code.
